etymology.description: 止 ‘foot’ + 一 ‘the beginning place’; originally written as 㞢, meaning ‘to go’.
etymology.interpretation: Combines a foot with a starting mark to picture setting off or moving forward. The footprint element later reduced to a dot, and the streamlined graph came to serve broad grammatical functions in Classical Chinese such as a genitive/objet pronoun.

examples.chinese: 此事之因，尚难尽述(此事之因，尚難盡述)。
examples.pinyin: Cǐ shì zhī yīn, shàng nán jìn shù.
examples.english: The cause of this matter is hard to fully explain.

examples.chinese: 我之前没见过他(我之前沒見過他)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ zhīqián méi jiàn guò tā.

examples.chinese: 取之不尽，用之不竭(取之不盡，用之不竭)。
examples.pinyin: Qǔ zhī bù jìn, yòng zhī bù jié.
examples.english: Take from it without end; use it without exhausting it.
